title: 115_s2399
content: The "American Innovation $1 Coin Act" is the short title of the Act. It establishes the American Innovation $1 Coin Program. Section 5112 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include a new subsection for the redesign and issuance of $1 coins honoring innovation and innovators from each state, the District of Columbia, and each territory starting in 2019. The coins will be known as 'American Innovation $1 coins' with designs selected in accordance with specified criteria. The Secretary will mint and issue $1 coins honoring Native Americans and their contributions in accordance with subsection (r), with a design on the reverse selected in 2018 to introduce the series of coins. The subsection describes the design requirements for a $1 coin honoring American innovators, including specific inscriptions and edge-incusing, with design approval by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The subsection defines the territories eligible for the $1 coin design requirements, including the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the United States Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The design must feature a dramatic representation of the Statue of Liberty on the obverse side of the coin. The $1 coin design requirements include the obverse side featuring the Statue of Liberty and the reverse side depicting an image related to innovation from one of the 50 States, the District of Columbia, or the territories of the United States. The $1 coin design requirements mandate the edge-incusing of the year of minting, mint mark, and 'E Pluribus Unum' inscription to preserve the coin's distinctive edge for easy identification, including by individuals who are blind or visually impaired. The $1 coin designs must include edge-incusing of the year of minting, mint mark, and 'E Pluribus Unum' inscription for easy identification by individuals who are blind or visually impaired. Coins commemorating innovation or innovators from each State, the District of Columbia, or a territory will be issued in alphabetic order, starting with Alabama. Four designs will be issued each year for 14 years. The Secretary will issue coins featuring innovations or innovators from each State, the District of Columbia, and territories until one coin per entity has been issued. The number of coins for each design will be determined by the Secretary based on relevant factors. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue $1 coins for additional states or territories admitted into the Union during the 14-year period. This is in addition to the four $1 coins issued each year for existing entities. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue $1 coins for states or territories admitted into the Union during a 14-year period. The selection of the significant innovation or innovator for the reverse of the coin will be made by the Secretary of the Treasury after consultation with the Governor or chief executive. If a territory becomes independent before $1 coins are minted, this subsection will no longer apply to that territory. The Secretary of the Treasury selects designs for $1 coins after consulting with the Governor or chief executive of the state, District of Columbia, or territory. The designs are also reviewed by the Commission of Fine Arts and Citizens Coinage. The Secretary of the Treasury selects designs for $1 coins after consulting with the Governor or chief executive of the state, District of Columbia, or territory. Proposals for designs may be submitted according to the Secretary's approval process, ensuring dignified designs are chosen, and prohibiting certain representations like head and shoulders portraits. The Secretary of the Treasury selects designs for $1 coins in consultation with state officials. Designs must be dignified and not include head and shoulders portraits of living individuals. The coins are considered numismatic items and can be minted in uncirculated and proof qualities. The program will end once an innovation from each state, the District of Columbia, and each territory has been honored. The program to select designs for $1 coins in consultation with state officials will end once an innovation from each state, the District of Columbia, and each territory has been honored and may not be resumed except by an Act of Congress.
